subject: US SERVICE IS NOW CLOSED
RANsquawk Week in Focus: 2nd - 6th April 2018 - Now available in the Research Suite
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

subject: RANSQUAWK SERVICE SCHEDULE OVER EASTER
content:
The desk will operate its usual schedule until Thursday March 29th 2130BST upon which the desk will close and remain closed for the entirety of Friday 30th March in observance of Good Friday with UK, EU and US markets all closed. 

The Service will resume on Sunday April 1st at 2200BST for the beginning of the Asia-Pac session and will run until Monday 2nd April at 0630BST at which point the service will halt due to the closure of EU and UK markets. The service will then resume at 1300BST for the beginning of the US session with US markets subject to a regular open.

subject: US MARKET WRAP: Stocks up, Treasuries up, USD flat, oil higher
content:
*SNAPSHOT: Stocks up, Treasuries up, USD flat, oil higher
*REAR-VIEW: Good claims data, Poor Canadian GDP, PCE in-line
*AHEAD: Kashkari Thursday night, Bank Holiday Friday, US ISM data on Monday

* EQUITIES: SPX +1.40% at 2642 , NDX +1.86% at 6581 , DJI +1.29% at 24156
* SECTORS: CONS CYC (XLY): +1.39%, CONS NON-CYC (XLP): +0.84%, ENERGY (XLE): +2.40%, FINANCIALS (XLF): +1.42%, HEALTH CARE (XLV): +1.19%, INDUSTRIALS (XLI): +1.82%, MATERIALS (XLB): +2.10%, TECH (XLK): +2.61%, TELECOMS (XTL): +0.34%, UTLITIES (XLU): +0.70%.
* Despite finishing green on Thursday, SPX snaps nine consecutive quarters of gains to finish Q1 in the red. Trade was subdued ahead of the long weekend/month-end/quarter-end, with most of the rebalancing seemingly completed on Wednesday. Gains were broad-based, with all sectors green; tech led the gains, with the much-watched FAANG names positive – Amazon recovering from a slide after negative tweets from US President Trump.

* CRUDE: WTI futures (May) settle 56 cents higher at USD 64.94 per barrel, WTI (June) settles 52 cents higher at $64.87.
* Traders continue to balance bearish  fundamentals (rising supply, with the suggestion that demand could ease in the months/quarters ahead) with rising geopolitical tensions (will the US re-apply sanctions on Iran in May?). But on Thursday, crude took its cue from a favourable risk backdrop, finishing the session in the black, rounding off the its third straight quarter of gains. At the margin, continued positive OPEC chatter was cited by some traders, and after reports from Saudi Arabia on Wednesday that oil producers were weighing extending cooperation on supply cuts, today it was reported that Russian policymakers were mulling the notion. Elsewhere, a Reuters poll showed analysts revised their 2018 forecasts for Brent and WTI higher (to $63.97 and $59.85 per barrel, respectively).

* FOREX: DXY ENDS Q1 DOWN, FIFTH STRAIGHT QUARTER OF DECLINES.
* It is difficult to infer much significance from Thursday’s FX trade on account of month/quarter-end, as well as traders wrapping up early for the long Easter weekend. This left EUR more-or-less unchanged clinging to the 1.23 region. Overnight, the JPY saw profit taking near 107.00, and along with lower US yields, USDJPY moved towards 106.30, before settling around the 106.50 mark. GBP trades lower after weaker-than-expected house price data, though the 1.40 level holds. Firmer risk sentiment helped the AUD, NZD and CAD make gains against the buck, though AUDUSD struggles with the 0.77 handle; NZD had a look beneath the 0.72 area, though made its way back above the level; CAD continues to patrol the 1.28-1.2950 range. EMFX is generally higher on positive risk.

* FIXED INCOME: US 10-Year T-Note Futures Settle 8 ticks higher at 121-05.
* Treasuries bull-flattened in thin volume trade. Traders largely ignored the data slate today, despite core PCE ticking up in-line with expectations. The flattening theme continued, with 2s30s printing fresh lows under 70bps (all major spreads were tighter).

At the margin, continued positive OPEC chatter was cited by some traders, and after reports from Saudi Arabia on Wednesday that oil producers were weighing extending cooperation on supply cuts, today it was reported that Russian policymakers were mulling the notion. Elsewhere, a Reuters poll showed analysts revised their 2018 forecasts for Brent and WTI higher (to $63.97 and $59.85 per barrel, respectively).

subject: Weekly FX Wrap: Dollar still down, but off worst levels at the end of Q1
content:
DXY

It’s been a bad first quarter of the year for the Greenback overall, but the index has clawed back some losses over the final 3 trading sessions of the month to get back within touching distance of the 90.000 level within a broader 92.640-88.253 range.

The Dollar reprieve is largely due to several bank portfolios flagging buy signals for the end of March (one ‘strong and across the board’), which of course also coincides with the end of Q1 and Japan’s financial year.

JPY    

Not quite zero from hero, but amidst selling interest from domestic importers and a mega M&A (on paper at least) the Jpy reversed coursed sharply in the run in to the turn, as the headline pair posted its largest single day rise of 2018 so far and biggest in pip terms for over 2 years. In terms of Q1, Usd/Jpy has tumbled from 113.05 to a low of 104.55, and currently around 106.35 (30 DMA) with decent option expiry interest between 106.40-50 (1.1 bn).

AUD/NZD

A similar pattern for the antipodeans vs the Usd, with global trade war jitters and in particular concerns about the US-Chinese tariff tiff repercussions undermining earlier appreciation in the quarter. Aud/Usd was trading up at 0.8135 in late January, but reversed to a low of circa 0.7640 on the penultimate session of this month with the next major tech support seen at 0.7600 and a big expiry (1.2 bn) also underpinning vs macro offers at 0.7680 (latter now being tested after a weak Chicago PMI). Nzd/Usd highs and lows have been less pronounced amidst more choppy and rangebound trade on balance, but 0.7200 is being challenged to the downside and a clean break could expose the 200 DMA (0.7185-80), with stops seen at 0.7175 and 0.7150.

CAD

Undermined by softer than expected GDP data today, but also other recent release and ongoing NAFTA uncertainty as negotiations continue amidst some reports that an accord is still remote with time running out before Mexican elections at the end of April. Usd/Cad is pivoting around 1.2900, and much closer to 1.3100+ peaks vs circa 1.2250 lows.

EUR/GBP

Both net winners vs the Usd since the start of 2018, the former on an increasingly more hawkish or less dovish ECB and the latter due to signs of progress on the Brexit front and a transition deal between the UK and EU. Eur/Usd straddling 1.2300 at present, with big stops seen at 1.2295 ahead of the 4pm fix, Cable holding just above 1.4050 vs a peak this year around 1.4345 and trough at 1.3455.

• General Electric (GE) – The co. has been mentioned cautiously after Berkshire Hathaway (BRK.A) speculation. (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) – The car co.’s shareholders which are against the Solarcity merger win a court battle against said merger. (Newswires)

  • American River (AMRB) upgraded to Outperform from Market Perform at Fig Partners

subject: Barclays (BARC LN) has agreed to pay USD 2bln in settlement with US DoJ to resolve claims for fraud related to RMBS sales
reaction_details: • Barclays shares spiked higher after this report as some analysts were expecting the company to have received a larger fine after Deutsche Bank previously settled for USD 7.2bln and JPM agreed a USD 13bln fine.
analysis_details:
• Previously there had been reports on Sky News two weeks that suggested RBS had set aside in excess of GBP 2.5bln to cover similar fines and RBS shares have also moved higher after these reports. 
  •

subject: DAILY US EQUITY OPENING NEWS - Earnings from Constellation Brands (STZ), PVH Corp. (PVH) and Gamestop (GME)
content:
29th March 2018

EARNINGS

  • Constellation Brands (STZ) Q4 EPS USD 1.90 vs Exp. USD 1.75, Revenue USD 1.77bln vs Exp. USD 1.75bln. Raises cash dividend to USD 0.74/shr from USD 0.67/shr. (Newswires)
  • Finish Line (FINL) Q4 EPS USD 0.59 vs Exp. USD 0.57, revenue USD 561.3mln vs Exp. USD 577.47mln. CSS fell 7.9%. (Newswires)
  • GameStop (GME) Q4 EPS USD 2.02 vs Exp. USD 1.97, Revenue USD 3.5bln vs Exp. USD 3.27bln. (Newswires)
  • PVH Corp. (PVH) Q4 EPS USD 1.58 vs Exp. USD 1.48, Revenue USD 2.5bln vs Exp. USD 2.35bln. (Newswires)

DJIA

  • Boeing (BA) – The jet manufacturer says they found a limited intrusion of malware. Separately, BOC Aviation unit to buy six 787-9 Boeing aircraft for USD 1.7B. (Newswires)
  • Walmart (WMT) – The retail giants announced a goal to reduce greenhouse gas emissions in China by 50mln metric tons by 2030. (Newswires)

S&P500

  • AT&T (T) / Time Warner (TWX) – A judge has warned attorneys to speed up the trial or it risks missing the June 21st deadline to complete the deal. (Newswires)
  • CME Group (CME) - The co. is to acquire NEX Group (NXG LN) for GBP 10.00 per share, valued at USD 5.5bln. (Newswires)
  • CVS Health (CVS) - The co. is facing a federal lawsuit claiming the company unintentionally revealed the HIV status of up to 6,000 Ohio residents though a prescription mailing. (Newswires)
  • FirstEnergy (FE) – The energy co. has filed a deactivation notice for three nuclear plants. (Newswires)
  • General Motors (GM) – The automakers Korean unit requests the U.S. headquarters rolls over USD 929M in debt due in April. (Newswires)
  • HP (HPQ) – The tech co. COO John Flaxman has passed away names Jos Brenkel as interim COO. (Newswires)
  • Oil names (CVX, XOM) – The co.’s are to bid for Brazil offshore stakes despite the legal block. (Newswires)
  • McCormick (MKC) – The co. raised its quarterly dividend 11% to USD 0.52 per share. (Newswires)
  • Nvidia (NVDA) - The tech co.’s CEO says that Uber does not use Nvidia's Drive technology. (Newswires)
  • Zimmer Biomet Holdings (ZBH) – The co. says outcomes are positive from Mobi-C trial validate strengths. (Newswires)

NASDAQ 100

  • Amazon (AMZN) – US President Trump tweets saying his problems with the retail giant were stated long before the election. And a White House spokesman says tax policies need to catch up to the co. (Newswires)
  • Broadcom (AVGO) - The co. principal accounting officer sells 5,000 ordinary shares at a price of USD 249.859 per share. (Newswires)
  • Shire (SHPG) – The co. has said the European Medicines Agency has validated its marketing authorisation application for Lanadelumab, a preventing medicine for angioedema attacks (Newswires)
  • Tesla (TSLA) - The automakers Q1 deliveries are likely to miss estimates, deutsche says. Separately, the magazine Popular Mechanics named Tesla’s Model 3 as its Car of the Year. Also, its German customers can now apply for subsidies again when purchasing Tesla cars. (Newswires)

OTHER NEWS

  • Acxiom (ACXM) / Facebook (FB) – Acxiom was informed by Facebook that Facebook Partner Categories will be discontinued over the next several months. In line with reports from Recode that Facebook is to cut third party data providers out of ad targeting. (Newswires / Recode)
  • AMC Entertainment Holdings (AMC) / Citi (C) – AMC is working with Citi on a potential IPO of Odeon cinemas group, this could value it at more than USD 2bln. (Newswires)
  • Assured Guaranty (AGO) – The co.’s CEO has urged the Puerto Rico Electric Power Authority to work with creditors. (Newswires)
  • BioMarin (BMRN) – The co. says European Medicines Agency has accepted the submission of Marketing Authorisation Application for Pegvaliase, (Newswires)
  • Brown & Brown (BRO) – The co. has completed its 2-for-1 stock split. (Newswires)
  • Bunge (BG) – The co. signed share purchase agreement regarding the potential acquisition by Corbion of the co.’s stake in SB Renewables Joint Venture. (Newswires)
  • Cabot Microelectronics Corporation (CCMP) – The co. and Fujimi Incorporated have announced plans to collaborate in the development of certain advanced IC CMP solutions for the semiconductor industry. (Newswires)
  • Celanese (CE) – The co. has announced price increases on products such as 30c/kg on its Hostaform / Celcon Polyacetal grades. (Newswires)
  • DST Systems (DST) / SS&C (SSNC) – DST Systems shareholders have approved a merger with SS&C. (Newswires)
  • H.B. Fuller (FUL) - The co. CEO expects pricing improvements to continue. (Newswires)
  • Heron Therapeutics (HRTX) - The co. has announced a common stock offering and a 19mln spot secondary with a price range of USD 25.00 to USD 26.00. (Newswires)
  • Overstock.com (OSTK) – The co. has cancelled its 4m share secondary stock offering. (Newswires)
  • Pandora (P) – The co. is to challenge Spotify with personalised playlists. (Tech Crunch)
  • Pembina Pipeline (PBA) – The co. announces Alliance Pipeline open season for expansion capacity commitments. (Newswires)
  • Post Holdings (POST) – The co. has announced it is to propose an IPO of its private brands business. (Newswires)
  • Spectrum Brands (SPB) / Energizer (ENR) – Energizer and Spectrum Brands announce expiration of Hart-Scott-Rodino waiting period, which helps one of the conditions of the pending transaction between the two companies. (Newswires)
  • Taubman Centers (TCO) – The co. announces a 650,000-share block trade with a price range of USD 57.20 to USD 57.40. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

Upgrades

  • AKAMAI (AKAM) UPGRADED TO EQUAL WEIGHT FROM UNDERWEIGHT AT MORGAN STANLEY

subject: Canada GDP YY (Jan) 2.7% vs. Exp. 2.9% (Prev. 3.3%, Rev. 3.4%)
analysis_details: There was little by way of sustained USD reaction after the US data, with the moves in CAD standing out. USDCAD jumped from 1.2895 to 1.2940, driven by the weaker than forecast Canada GDP and PPI data. However, the knee-jerk reaction was short-lived, and USDCAD pared back gains settling around the 1.2915 region.

subject: Scotiabank FX Daily - USD Steady Into Month/Quarter End; Remain Bearish
content:
•   USD medium-term risks still tilted to the downside; look to losses in April.
  •   CAD quiet heading into January GDP; we maintain a bullish medium-term view.
  •   EUR stabilizes around 1.23; ECB’s Knot supports bond buy phase out in Sept.
  •   GBP quiet around 1.4050; current account deficit narrows; GDP unchanged.
  •   JPY attempting modest stabilization after bearish reversal from Monday.
  •   AUD recovering from fresh 2018 low in mid 0.76s; RBA meets April 3.
  •   MXN is firm heading into quarter end, pushing back toward 2018 high.

subject: FIXED AND FX LATEST: bonds narrowly mixed, Usd off peaks
content: Ahead of the early and heaviest US data deluge, core debt is still respecting intraday ranges and with Gilts maintaining mild outperformance despite weaker than forecast preliminary German CPI that was pretty much telegraphed by the state releases. However, the Dollar has softened somewhat and appears to have lost or at least is losing some of its hitherto relentless bullish momentum on the rebalancing models, which could indicate that the bulk of that buying is done – let’s see.

China FX regulator says China will improve FX reserves management capabilities this year and that it will steadily push forward financial market two way opening up this year
Constellation Brands (STZ) Q4 EPS USD 1.90 vs Exp. USD 1.75, Revenue USD  1.77bln vs Exp. USD 1.75bln
ECB’s Knot says bond buying should be phased out after September
content:
• New ECB forward guidance should focus on interest rates and notes it is appropriate to start discussing new guidance now
  • Relatively close to a sustained adjustment in inflation path
analysis_details: Similar to what he has said before, sticking to his more hawkish stance

subject: A confidential German military report says the current Airbus (AIR FP) A400M mission planning system is "not acceptable" for short term missions; the report cites continued problems with the plane
DAILY US OPENING NEWS: European bourses drifting higher heading into the long Easter weekend
content:
• European bourses drifting higher heading into the long Easter weekend
  • DXY stable around the 90.00 level
  • Looking ahead, highlights include national German CPI, US personal income, PCE, Canadian GDP, Fed’s Harker

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded indecisive as bourses failed to completely shrug-off the lacklustre lead from Wall St. where the major indices were subdued amid month-end flows and continued tech losses. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.6%) were mixed with Australia dragged lower by tech as well as recent weakness across commodities, while the Japanese benchmark was propped up for most the day by a softer currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (+0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+1.2%) were choppy in the midst of earnings season and with initial gains seen following reports of VAT reductions, although continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC and ongoing trade tensions with the US eventually weighed. Finally, 10yr JGBs were weaker as Japanese yields rose across the curve, with demand for paper sapped by initial outperformance in Japanese stocks and after an uninspiring 2yr auction in which the amount sold, b/c and accepted prices all declined from prior.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 40bln. (Newswires)

PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.3046 (Prev. 6.2785)

China State Council approved lowering of VAT rates effective May 1st as part of tax reduction package valued at CNY 400bln for 2018. (Newswires)

CENTRAL BANKS

Fed’s Harker (non-voter, dovish) says expects three rate hikes this year, previously he projected two, citing stronger inflation. (Newswires)

TRADE TARIFFS

China Ministry of Commerce said it hopes US drops unilateralism and protectionism, while it also hopes US takes steps and resolves conflict with China through dialogue. Furthermore, Mofcom added that US action on trade is like opening a Pandora's box and that it sees spillover effects. (Newswires)

It was initially reported that US and are China in talks to shield soybeans from trade war, but this was later followed by conflicting overnight comments from the US Soybean Export Council that said China is still contemplating import curbs on US soybeans.  (SCMP/Newswires)

EU/UK/US

UK opposition Labour Party is likely to vote in favour of final Brexit deal, according to press reports. (Telegraph)

Italian President Mattarella to start talks on new government on April 4th.This follows the discussions and negotiations held between rival parties to form a coalition government. (Newswires)

UK Nationwide house price YY (Mar) 2.1% vs. Exp. 2.6% (Prev. 2.2%)

UK Nationwide house price mm (Mar) -0.2% vs. Exp. 0.2% (Prev. -0.3%, Rev. -0.4%)

UK GDP YY Final (Q4) 1.4% vs. Exp. 1.4% (Prev. 1.4%)

UK GDP QQ Final (Q4) 0.4% vs. Exp. 0.4% (Prev. 0.4%)

German Regional CPIs painted a similar picture to the National CPI expectation, with the YY readings above expectations and MM in line.

EQUITIES

European equities (Eurostoxx +1.2%) are back into positive territory, improving on the mixed tone seen in Asia overnight and shrugging-off the losses on Wall Street. Defensive sectors are in the red with focus on utilities and healthcare whilst broad gains are seen across all the other sectors. Sodexo (-14.1%) was the laggard this morning after reporting its earnings, dragging down Elior (-1.0%) and Compass (-3.6%) in the UK food catering segment. SwissRE (+2.9%) is leading the SMI after Softbank is said to be interested in building a 25% stake in the Co. for a USD 9.6bln deal. TomTom suffered losses of 6.3% after approaching Deutsche Bank for a potential sale of the whole firm or minority stake, but then denied calling for an adviser to seek potential buyers. Finally, as a reminder, Melrose’s GBP 8bln hostile bid for GKN is due to expire today at 1300 BST.

FX

The Greenback is showing little sign of losing its month, quarter and Japanese FY end bid, although the DXY is only tentatively above the 90.000 handle and the Dollar is somewhat mixed against its G10 rivals. Usd/Jpy is hovering just above 106.50 having touched 107.00 overnight after the biggest 1 day jump this year so far and with near term support seen at the 30 DMA (106.35). Aud/Usd has recovered some poise after hitting a fresh 2018 low around 0.7644 overnight but looks capped ahead of macro supply seen at 0.7680 vs major support at 0.7600 where hefty option expiry interest also resides (1.2 bn). Usd/Cad remains close to 1.2900 amidst less positive NAFTA vibes (long way to go to reach a deal and US demands on food not palatable), and with the Loonie now looking towards Canadian GDP data for some independent direction. Eur/Usd looks anchored around 1.2300 with strong support and resistance not far from the round number at 1.2286 and 1.2329 (latter representing the 30 DMA) and little to offer impetus via German jobs or inflation data given outcomes relatively close to consensus. Cable is clinging to 1.4050 (just) having lost grip of 1.4200 and 1.4100 handles on the run in to the end of March and long Easter weekend amidst decent expiries at the latter level and 1.4000, while techs are also wary of a fib at 1.4041. Nzd/Usd sits near 0.7200 and Usd/Chf is just above 0.9550.

FIXED INCOME

Debt markets remain comparatively subdued in terms of price action and traded volume, but Bunds and Gilts have both seen further topside activity with the former up to 159.35 and briefly above parity, albeit only +4 ticks. The core UK debt future continues to outperform and reached 122.84 at one stage (+19 ticks) on the back of more bullish month end duration dynamics but lost a little momentum in wake of the UK data that revealed a few better than expected components. US Treasuries somewhat side-lined ahead of some key macro releases to come but retaining a marginally firmer and flatter bias after the heavy supply taken down in the past few days (7 year auction the least well received despite its usual popularity with foreign investors and perhaps a sign of global trade wars adversely impacting demand).

COMMODITIES

Taking a look at the commodities complex, WTI (+0.3%) and Brent Crude (+0.1%) are trading in close proximity to yesterday’s post-DoE levels. Prices have also been supported by yesterday’s comments from OPEC stating the producer cartel and other suppliers are looking to continue withholding the output cut for the rest of the year and potentially 2019. Moving on to metals, Gold is trading close to the prior session’s lows where the yellow metal posted its biggest 1-day percentage fall in almost 9 months as it continues to move inversely to the dollar. Base metals have seen a rebound in prices on the London Metal Exchange with Nickel (+2.0%) leading the advance and copper (+1.0%) higher following recent declines.

subject: Fed’s Harker (non-voter, dovish) says expects three rate hikes this year, previously he projected two, citing stronger inflation
EU MID-SESSION UPDATE: European bourses grasp a firm footing heading into the end of March and long Easter weekend
content:

The IT sector (-0.4%) extends losses after yesterday’s tech sell-off across the board, defensive sectors also into the red with focus on utilities and healthcare whilst broad gains are seen across all the other sectors. subject: Gilts remain relatively resilient, Short Sterling strip also showing some steel
content: UK debt and STIR futures have recovered from early Liffe wobbles to trade flat to slightly firmer amidst typically choppy month-end trade, but with Gilts still benefiting from an extremely extended end of March index duration and outperforming core fixed equivalents. The 10 year benchmark was initially marked down quite heavily to 122.48 vs Wednesday’s 122.65 close, but met underlying bids immediately to trade back up at 122.73 before fading, while the 3 month curve has turned 1-3 tick losses into 1-2 tick gains, albeit still slightly steeper after recent flattening. Some domestic data to digest ahead via the last Q4 GDP reading, mortgage lending, consumer credit and the current account.

subject: Renault – Nissan spokesperson declines to comment on merger rumours
ECB says banks borrowed EUR 131mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 673.1bln
ECB says banks borrowed EUR 131mln at marginal rate & deposited EUR 673.1bln
Renault (RNO FP) and Nissan (7201 JT) are said to be in talks to merge and create a new company
reaction_details: • in an immediate reaction, Renault shares rose to EUR 100.36 from EUR 93.82

subject: Morning EU Movers: Swiss Re (SREN SW) +2.8%, Telecom Italia (TIT IM) +1.75%, Nex Group (NXG LN) -1.0%, Shire (SHP LN) -1.1%, Compass (CPG LN) -3.3%, TomTom (TOM2) -6.3%
Bunds: losing more momentum as global equities show some signs of stabilisation
content: A softer Eurex open on the back of considerably less risk-off sentiment compared to recent sessions, although global stock markets are still on the defensive awaiting further developments on the trade war front, and especially US vs Chinese manoeuvres. The final month/Q1/Japanese FY portfolio positioning will also play a pivotal role ahead of the long Easter weekend and there is a packed schedule to come with the Eurozone focus on first snapshots of inflation for March via preliminary data from Germany’s reporting states before the national reading. CPI is expected to pick-up pace this month and will obviously feed into ECB thinking given recent concerns about the slow progress towards target, and especially in terms of underlying prices. Back to Eurex, and the range so far for the 10 year German bond is 159.29-14 vs yesterday’s 159.31 close, while the yield has ticked back up to just over 0.5%. Staying with inflation, but on the US side PCE metrics are due and the preferred measure for Fed policy purposes.

subject: Additional European equity stories post the release of the Daily European equity opening news
content:
NEX Group (NXG LN) - CME (CME) are to buy NEX Group in a cash and stock deal valued at GBP 3.9bln. (Newswires)

Mediclinic (MDC LN) – Co. has announced Van Der Merwe as the successor to CEO Meint Jas. (Newswires)

Orange (ORA FP) – Co. are looking at an M&A opportunity with Nethys, according to sources. (Newswires)

SSE (SSE LN) – Co. guides FY adj. EPS at just above GBP 1.20. (Newswires)

Shire (SHP LN) – Co. announces a regulatory milestone for Lanadelumab. (Newswires)

Banking sector – Japan’s antitrust watchdog FTC warns Deutsche Bank (DBK GY) and Bank of America Merrill Lynch (BAC) over alleged bond-price fixing in 2012. (Newswires)

Compass (CPG LN) -Negative read from Sodexo after weak Q2 performance. (Newswires)

Capita (CPI LN) – No longer in the running for British Airway’s call centres. (Newswires) 

ENEL (ENEL IM) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM NEUTRAL AT ODDO SECURITIES

DEUTSCHE BANK REMAIN UNDERWEIGHT EUROPEAN EQUITIES VS US

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN EQUITY OPENING NEWS: Highlights include stories from Shire, GKN and Swiss Re
content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

29th March 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded indecisive as bourses failed to completely shrug-off the lacklustre lead from Wall St. where the major indices were subdued amid month-end flows and continued tech losses. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were mixed with Australia dragged lower by tech as well as recent weakness across commodities, while the Japanese benchmark was propped up for most the day by a softer currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) were choppy in the midst of earnings season and with initial gains seen following reports of VAT reductions, although continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC and ongoing trade tensions with the US eventually weighed.

FTSE

Shire (SHP LN) – According to the FT Lex column, Takeda purchasing Shire could be quite a stretch given the Co.’s market cap compared to that of Shire’s. The column goes on to say that the approach could inspire other potential suitors including Novartis (NOVN SW), Pfizer (PFE) and AbbVie (ABBV). (FT)

Royal Mail (RMG LN) – Members of CWU voted overwhelmingly in favour of agreement in principle on pensions, pay, shorter working week, culture and operational changes. (Newswires)

GKN (GKN LN) – Co. is planning to sell 90% of its GBP 10bln empire, according to the final attack on the company by Melrose (MRO LN) ahead of today’s 1300BST deadline. (The Times)

GSK (GSK LN) - A federal judge overturned on Wednesday a US jury’s verdict that required Teva Pharmaceuticals to pay the Co. more than USD 235mln over the infringement of blood pressure drug Coreg. (Newswires)

Ex-Dividends - British Land (BLND LN), Intercontinental Hotel Group (IHG LN) and (Prudential PRU LN) will trade without entitlement to their latest dividend pay-out on Thursday, trimming 3.88 points off the FTSE 100. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Nex Group (NXG LN) – The co. confirms it received a non-binding proposal from CME group (CME) regarding an acquisition of USD 10/shr and notes discussions are at an advanced stage and notes there can be no certainty than an offer for the co. will be made. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PROVIDENT FINANCIAL (PFG LN) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM HOLD AT BERENBERG

DAX

Auto names – The country’s new Finance Minister Scholz said Germany must do all it can to avert driving bans for diesel cars. Additionally he urged cities and local communities to boost investments in charging stations for electric cars. (Newswires)

OTHER GERMAN COMPANIES

K+S (SDF GY) – The Indian cabinet slashed subsidies for potash-based fertiliser by over 10% for the next fiscal year starting April 1st , as the world’s leading importer of the fertiliser attempts to contain a fiscal deficit. (Newswires)

Rhoen-Klinikum (RHK GY) – FY 2017 revenue EUR 1.21bln vs. Prelim EUR 1.21bln, EBITDA EUR 97.8mln vs. Prelim EUR 98mln and net EUR 36.7mln vs. Prev. EUR 58.6mln. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

ALLIANZ (ALV GY) DOWNGRADED TO NEUTRAL FROM OVERWEIGHT AT JP MORGAN CHASE

BASF (BAS GY) UPGRADED TO BUY FROM HOLD AT HSBC

CAC

Sanofi (SAN FP) – EMA is to review a potential treatment for type 1 diabetes called Sotagliflozin. (Newswires)

Sodexo (SW FP) – H1 net EUR 372mln vs. Prev. EUR 348mln, revenue EUR 10.3bln vs. Prev. EUR 10.6bln and underlying operating profit EUR 627mln vs. Prev. EUR 738mln.  Co. cuts 2018 guidance. (Newswires)

OTHER FRENCH COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

SCOR (SCR FP) DOWNGRADED TO SELL FROM NEUTRAL AT GOLDMAN SACHS

PAN-EUROPE

TomTom (TOM2 NA) - Reportedly hired Deutsche Bank for a potential sale of whole firm or minority stake, according to sources. However the co. denies it had hired an adviser to seek potential buyers. (Newswires)

Telecom Italia (TIT IM) – Elliot Advisors does not think the Co.’s shareholders will need to pick a new board in May if they agree over the board candidates suggested by the activist investor in next month’s meeting, the hedge fund reported on Wednesday. Separately, a market analysis carried out by AGCOM over the Co.’s fixed line network is to be completed by the end of July, according to one of its commissioners on Wednesday. (Newswires) 

Atlantia (ATL IM) – HSBC held a potential stake of 5.703% as of March 13th. (Newswires)

Ubi Banca (UBI IM) – HSBC held a potential sake of 6.224% as of March 13th. (Newswires)

SMI

Nestle (NESN) – The co. has reportedly hired advisors to sell its Gerber Life insurance unit which could be valued at USD 1bln. Separately, Co. publishes 2017 restated group figures, changes reflect new accounting standards and changes to nutrition business. Revenue is altered to CHF 89.6bln from CHF 89.8bln. (Insurance Insider / Newswires)

Swiss Re (SREN SW) – Japan’s Softbank (9984 JT) is considering purchasing a 25% stake in the Co. worth around USD 9.6bln as the talk over a potential deal advance. (Newswires)

OTHER SWISS COMPANIES

BROKER MOVES

LINDT & SPRUENGLI (LISN SW) DOWNGRADED TO HOLD FROM BUY AT BERENBERGSCANDINAVIA

BROKER MOVES

US

* EQUITIES: SPX -0.31% at 2605, DJI -0.04% at 23848, NDX -1.06% at 6460.

Sectors: Telecoms +1.7%, Non-cyclicals +1.5%, Health +0.6%, Financials +0.4%, Utilities -0.2%, Industrials -0.5%, Tech -0.6%, Cyclicals -1.2%, Materials -1.3%, Energy -1.9%.

* Tuesday's tech sell-off spread into Asia, which then spread into European trade, though S&P 500 eminis were horizontal overnight and through the European morning. The cash contract was meandering around the neutral line for most of US trade. Defensives were better performers amid a generally soft risk tone. Most FAANG saw another day of selling (though Alphabet and FB fared well). In stock specifics, a number of brokerages cut their estimates for AAPL iPhone production in Q2 citing soft demand for high-end smartphones. For CVS and AET, an FDA official expressed concerns about consolidation within the pharmacy benefit management sector. In M&A, CACI withdrew its offer to buy CSRA (GD also recently made an offer). And in earnings, WBA beat on the top and bottom lines.

subject: DAILY EUROPEAN OPENING NEWS: Asian equity markets traded indecisive as bourses failed to completely shrug-off the lacklustre lead from Wall St.
content:
• Asian equity markets traded indecisive as bourses failed to completely shrug-off the lacklustre lead from Wall St.
  • The greenback pared some of the prior day’s strength with the DXY now back below the 90.00 level
  • Looking ahead, highlights include regional and nation German CPI, UK GDP (F), US personal income, PCE, Canadian GDP, Fed’s Harker


TRADE

China Ministry of Commerce said it hopes US drops unilateralism and protectionism, while it also hopes US takes steps and resolves conflict with China through dialogue. Furthermore, Mofcom added that US action on trade is like opening a Pandora's box and that it sees spillover effects. (Newswires)

It was initially reported that US and are China in talks to shield soybeans from trade war, but this was later followed by conflicting overnight comments from the US Soybean Export Council that said China is still contemplating import curbs on US soybeans.  (SCMP/Newswires)

Canada’s Chief NAFTA negotiator said there’s quite a bit of work to be done on a deal and that US proposals on food packaging are not acceptable. (Newswires)
 

ASIA

Asian equity markets traded indecisive as bourses failed to completely shrug-off the lacklustre lead from Wall St. where the major indices were subdued amid month-end flows and continued tech losses. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were mixed with Australia dragged lower by tech as well as recent weakness across commodities, while the Japanese benchmark was propped up for most the day by a softer currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.4%) were choppy in the midst of earnings season and with initial gains seen following reports of VAT reductions, although continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC and ongoing trade tensions with the US eventually weighed. Finally, 10yr JGBs were weaker as Japanese yields rose across the curve, with demand for paper sapped by initial outperformance in Japanese stocks and after an uninspiring 2yr auction in which the amount sold, b/c and accepted prices all declined from prior.

PBoC skipped open market operations for a net daily drain of CNY 40bln. (Newswires)
PBoC sets CNY mid-point at 6.3046 (Prev. 6.2785)

China State Council approved lowering of VAT rates effective May 1st as part of tax reduction package valued at CNY 400bln for 2018. (Newswires)
 

UK/EU

UK GfK Consumer Confidence (Mar) -7 vs. Exp. -10 (Prev. -10). (Newswires)
UK Lloyds Business Barometer (Mar) 32 (Prev. 33)

UK opposition Labour Party is likely to vote in favour of final Brexit deal, according to press reports. (Telegraph)


FX

The greenback pared some of the prior day’s strength with the DXY now back below the 90.00 level. This provided mild reprieve for EUR/USD which also found support at 1.2300, while GBP/USD was less encouraging and briefly extended on its descent below the 1.4100 handle. Elsewhere, USD/JPY pulled back after hitting resistance at 107.00 and on some position squaring heading into fiscal year-end, while commodity-linked currencies remained lacklustre following the recent downside across the complex.


COMMODITIES

Commodities trade quietened overnight with WTI crude futures consolidating after yesterday’s post-DoE price swings in which an unexpected headline crude stockpile build dragged prices below the USD 64/bbl level for a 3rd consecutive negative settlement, before rebounding to back above the aforementioned level. Elsewhere, gold prices found some much needed respite from yesterday’s slump in which a strengthening greenback saw the precious metal shed the most in nearly 9 months, while copper benefitted from the slight improvement in risk tone.  

GEOPOLITICAL

South Korea and North Korea reportedly began high-level discussions at the border village as expected, while there were also reports that Japan is said to have gauged North Korea on the possibility of a bilateral summit. (Newswires)


US

Yields started out the day lower on risk-aversion, while portfolio re-balancing was also being cited ahead of month-end (extensions are said to be supportive this month). Naturally, there was focus on 10-year yields, after they moved below the 200dma. At settlement, the curve was mixed; there was more clarity in curve spreads, however, with 2s10s c.2bps flatter, 2s30s c.4bps flatter (to the narrowest since 2007), 5s10s 2bps flatter, and 5s30s 4bps flatter. 2s5s was relatively unchanged. This week's bumper supply out of the US Treasury was capped by a weak 7-year auction, which tailed by 1.9bps, with cover softer than recent averages. Other internals were also weak, with dealer take down rising to 32% (12 ppts higher than recent averages), while indirect participation was the lowest since Feb 2016. Yields ticked higher after the auction, moving into negative territory. US T-Note Futures (Jun) unchanged at 120-29.

Fed's Bostic (voter, dovish) said he believes the Fed needs to get back to a neutral rate and that a gradual approach to interest rates is better than big jumps. Bostic also noted that a rise in inflation is a reason to get the economy back to a neutral rate and that despite the low unemployment rate, they are not seeing any upward pressure in wages. (Newswires)

subject: UK February car production declined 4.4% Y/Y, according to Society of Motor Manufacturers & Traders
PBoC Adviser Sheng expects higher M2 growth for 2018, according to 21st Century Business Herald
Singapore Export Prices (Feb) Y/Y -2.0% (Prev. -2.3%); Import Prices (Feb) Y/Y 0.0% (Prev. -0.2%)
Singapore PPI (Feb) Y/Y -0.8% (Prev. -0.2%)
ASX 200 preliminary close is down by 0.6% at 5753
ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia traded choppy after Wall St's continued tech woes and heading into fiscal year-end
content: Asia equity markets traded indecisive as bourses failed to completely shrug-off the lacklustre lead from Wall St. where the major indices were subdued amid month-end flows and continued tech losses. ASX 200 (-0.5%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.1%) were mixed with Australia dragged lower by tech as well as recent weakness across commodities, while the Japanese benchmark was propped up for most the day by a softer currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (-0.2%) and Shanghai Comp. (+0.1%) were choppy in the midst of earnings season and with initial gains seen following reports of VAT reductions, although continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC and ongoing trade tensions with the US eventually weighed. Finally, 10yr JGBs were weaker as Japanese yields rose across the curve, with demand for paper sapped by initial outperformance in Japanese stocks and after an uninspiring 2yr auction in which the amount sold, b/c and accepted prices all declined from prior.

ASIA-PAC MID SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks are indecisive after Wall St's tech woes and ahead of fiscal year-end
content:
Asia equity markets trade indecisive as bourses fail to completely shrug-off the lacklustre lead from Wall St. where the major indices were subdued amid month-end flows and continued tech losses. ASX 200 (-0.4%) and Nikkei 225 (+0.7%) are mixed with Australia also dragged lower by tech as well as recent weakness across commodities, while the Japanese benchmark has been propped up by a softer currency. Elsewhere, Hang Seng (Unch) and Shanghai Comp. (Unch) are choppy in the midst of earnings season and with initial gains seen following reports of VAT reductions, although continued liquidity inaction by the PBoC and ongoing trade tensions with the US eventually weighed.

In FX markets, the greenback pared some of the prior day’s strength with the DXY now back below the 90.00 level. This provided mild reprieve for EUR/USD which also found support at 1.2300, while GBP/USD was less encouraging and marginally extended on its descent below the 1.4100 handle. Elsewhere, USD/JPY pulled back after hitting resistance at 107.00 and on some position squaring heading into fiscal year-end, while commodity-linked currencies remained lacklustre following the recent downside across the complex.

Finally, 10yr JGBs are weaker as Japanese yields rise across the curve, with demand for paper sapped by the outperformance in Japanese stocks and as participants await a 2yr auction later.

Other News
- China said to deepen VAT reform in which it will cut VAT in manufacturing sector to 16%, while it will also reduce VAT for agricultural products, transport and telecoms sectors. (Newswires)

- NDRC says to promote further connect in capital markets between mainland China and Hong Kong. (Newswires)
- US and China are reported to be in talks to shield soybeans from a trade war. (SCMP)
